tweets.full_text: TWEET 1/3  The 1st OHBM Equinox Twitter Conference (#OHBMx) starts in a few minutes. Tune in for 24 hours of neuroscience research from across the world! Use the hashtag #OHBMx for posting all the discussions and questions related to the conference.

Yu-Chi Chen @cyctbdbw*, A Fornito @AFornito, K Aquino @Kevin_M_Aquino

*Monash University

▶ Novel asymmetry signatures for subject identification

#Anatomy #Modeling #Tools

user.description: OHBM EquinoX Twitter conference 20/03/2020; 24 hrs of neuroimaging hijinx as Earth makes 1 rotation on its journey around the Sun! https://t.co/u4pQJ4AR8p
user.name: OHBMX

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @AFornito @Kevin_M_Aquino 1. We develop a shape asymmetry signature (SAS), which summarizes brain asymmetry across spatial scales. We show that individual’s SAS is a highly unique feature that allows accurate subject identification at relatively coarse spatial scales. #OHBMx

user.description: PhD Candidate at @BMH_Hub
user.name: Yu-Chi Chen

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @AFornito @Kevin_M_Aquino 2. We used longitudinal images from 200 healthy participants from the OASIS-3. Following the framework of ShapeDNA (Reuter et al., 2006), we used Laplace-Beltrami eigenvalues (EVs) as global geometry descriptors of the cortical surface meshes. #OHBMx

user.description: PhD Candidate at @BMH_Hub
user.name: Yu-Chi Chen

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @AFornito @Kevin_M_Aquino 3. These EVs reflect spatial variation at discrete spatial scales. We subtracted the EVs spectra for white surface of the left hemisphere from those for the right hemisphere in the same subject at each scale, which we denote as the SAS for that subject. #OHBMx

Akram Zamani @AkiZamani*, D Wright @D_K_Wright, L Willis, L Dill, T O'Brien @brien_terence, B Semple @SciSemple

*Monash University

▶ White matter dynamics post paediatric traumatic brain injury IN MICE

#Developmental #Neurology #Social

user.description: OHBM EquinoX Twitter conference 20/03/2020; 24 hrs of neuroimaging hijinx as Earth makes 1 rotation on its journey around the Sun! https://t.co/u4pQJ4AR8p
user.name: OHBMX

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @Will_T_OBrien @brien_terence @shultz_sandy 4. Fixed-based analysis of fibre density revealed robust differences between afl controls and recently concussed afl athletes at 48 hrs post-injury. https://t.co/buFJcX38Wd

@OHBMequinoX @Will_T_OBrien @brien_terence @shultz_sandy 5. Significantly, although afl athletes were asymptomatic there was still evidence of brain changes 2 weeks later. These results may indicate increased cerebral vulnerability that can persist beyond the resolution of symptoms that typically defines recovery. #OHBMx https://t.co/mxi0bhgNiA

@OHBMequinoX @D_K_Wright @brien_terence @SciSemple Hi 👋 1.#TBI is highly prevalent in children under 4. At this age the brain is incredibly plastic, with myelination and complex networks (eg those required for social interaction) not yet fully formed. As such, injury to the immature🧠is quite different to TBI in adults #OHBMx https://t.co/9aioDsTwZ2

user.description: PhD, 🧠 postdoctoral Research Fellow @CCSMonash

@OHBMequinoX 1. First, I hope everyone & their families are safe from the coronavirus! I also like to thank my lab & collaborators, who did the actual work: @pengwanghome Xiaolu Kong @rubykong92 @csabaorban @R_Liegeois Gustavo Deco, @martijnheuv @johndmurray

With that, let's start! #OHBMx https://t.co/WX7pW9q00u

user.description: brain imaging, machine learning, mental disorders, big data
user.name: Thomas Yeo

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @pengwanghome @rubykong92 @csabaorban @R_Liegeois @martijnheuv @johndmurray 2. A powerful approach to bridge microscale and macroscale brain organization is the use of large-scale biophysically-plausible circuit models of coupled brain regions. See work from @DrBreaky @ViktorJirsa @ar0mcintosh @_PetraRitter @pausanzleon @adeelrazi and many others. #OHBMx https://t.co/qufE9KlNGW

user.description: brain imaging, machine learning, mental disorders, big data
user.name: Thomas Yeo

These large-scale circuit models are powered by biophysically plausible local neural mass models (NMMs) mathematically linked by anatomical connections. The resulting large-scale circuit models can generate realistic fMRI with relatively low parametric complexity. #OHBMx https://t.co/vVgmcspvqG

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @pengwanghome @rubykong92 @csabaorban @R_Liegeois @martijnheuv @johndmurray @DrBreaky @ViktorJirsa @ar0mcintosh @_PetraRitter @pausanzleon @adeelrazi 5. The fit was a lot better in unseen test data. Without assuming the existence of a hierarchy, the estimated micro-circuit parameters revealed a large-scale gradient, matching well with a meta-analysis, T1/T2 myelin estimate, resting-fMRI principal gradient & histology. #OHBMx https://t.co/RjfBagE14a

But spatial coverage is limited compared to whole scalp coverage of EEG (affects localization of distal sources). EEG studies have located activity from deep sources such as hippocampus #OHBMx

1.Unavailability of open access EEG datasets.
2.Incapability to predict seizures using raw EEG.
3.Rise in time & computational cost due to excessive feature extraction.
4.DL algos too require abundant data.
5.Lack of efficient hardware applications. #OHBMx

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @ten_photos (1) Statistical testing remains the most popular approach to task-fMRI inference. However, with ample power, even the smallest effects will reach statistical significance. For big fMRI datasets, this leads to almost whole-brain activation, even with stringent correction. #OHBMx https://t.co/SKTG500sSv

user.description: Population Health DPhil. at Oxford University. Neuroimaging, functional MRI methods, Reproducibility and Open Science.
user.name: Alex Bowring

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @ten_photos (2) To address this, we developed Confidence Sets (CSs), 3D analogs of confidence intervals. Instead of testing for any activation, the CSs make confidence statements about brain regions where Cohen’s d effect sizes exceed, and fall short of, a given threshold value c. #OHBMx https://t.co/EtOxwpahzZ

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX 1 Brains span scales: function requires structures spanning many orders of magnitude. Individual neurons communicate by sending molecules across tiny gaps; regions communicate using long-range connections 10 million X larger. Neuroscience needs multi-scale tools! #OHBMx https://t.co/5p7jBzfWwm

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX 3. We used oscillating visual stimuli to create known neural oscillations and measured with fast (TR<400 ms) fMRI. We found neural oscillations up to 0.75 Hz, that were ten times larger than predicted by conventional models. So, fMRI signals can be surprisingly fast!   #OHBMx https://t.co/QU9NIuiOYB

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @oualid_benkarim @CaseyPaquola @saratheriver @J_Royer_ @TingsterX @hong_seok_jun @georg @sofievalk @misicbata @MilhamMichael @Neuro_Conn @the_mindwanders @BorisBernhardt 1/6 Ever wanted to make your own #corticalgradients? BrainSpace, the Python/MATLAB gradient connectivity toolbox, is your friend! In this thread I'll tell you what the toolbox does, and how you can turn your own data into beautiful gradients with only a few lines of code. #OHBMx

user.description: Science geek by day, gaming geek by night.
user.name: Reinder Vos de Wael

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @oualid_benkarim @CaseyPaquola @saratheriver @J_Royer_ @TingsterX @hong_seok_jun @georg @sofievalk @misicbata @MilhamMichael @Neuro_Conn @the_mindwanders @BorisBernhardt 2/6 #corticalgradients describe the largest axes of variance in the data. For example, the first gradient of functional connectivity describes a sensorimotor to default mode axis. For more examples see the presentations by @sofievalk, @caseypaquola #OHBMx https://t.co/5EjjQYF8P7

user.description: Science geek by day, gaming geek by night.
user.name: Reinder Vos de Wael

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @oualid_benkarim @CaseyPaquola @saratheriver @J_Royer_ @TingsterX @hong_seok_jun @georg @sofievalk @misicbata @MilhamMichael @Neuro_Conn @the_mindwanders @BorisBernhardt 3/6 Making your own gradients can be done with only a few lines of code! BrainSpace was built to be simple to use for beginners, whilst also providing the possibility for custom kernels and dimensionality reduction techniques for advanced users. #OHBMx https://t.co/gKSe47TfF2

user.description: Science geek by day, gaming geek by night.

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @oualid_benkarim @CaseyPaquola @saratheriver @J_Royer_ @TingsterX @hong_seok_jun @georg @sofievalk @misicbata @MilhamMichael @Neuro_Conn @the_mindwanders @BorisBernhardt 4/6 BrainSpace computes the similarity of each region (=affinity matrix) with a user-specified kernel. A dimensionality reduction technique decomposes this matrix into several gradients (=eigenvectors). These are sorted by their eigenvalues to determine their order. #OHBMx https://t.co/Lgfrby3WFI

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @anibalsolon @TingsterX @pierre_bellec @neuro_data @michaelmilham 1. We studied the reproducibility of group and individual level functional parcellations in two datasets: HNU1 ( n = 30; 10 scans x 10 mins per scan), and GSP ( n = 300; 2 scans x 6 mins per scan). All groups were age and gender matched young adults. #OHBMx

user.description: Neuroscientist interested in MRI, skill learning, AI, brain development, and #OpenScience. He/Him. At: @ChildMindInst @ChildMindRnD @OHBMOpen @OHBM_Trainees

Cortical and subcortical functional parcellations were created in each of these datasets at group and individual levels. We compared the stability of the individual and group parcellations with and without bagging. #OHBMx

We found that: compared to standard clustering approaches, bagging-enhanced parcellations have much higher between scan, between session, between sample, and between study reproducibility! And this effect replicates across scanners, sites, clustering algorithms etc. #OHBMx

#OHBMx-61 ✳ #talk

Vaibhav Tripathi @vaibhav_3pathi*

*Boston University

▶ Gender Differences in Cortical fMRI Activity while Movie Watching

#Connectivity #Networks

user.description: OHBM EquinoX Twitter conference 20/03/2020; 24 hrs of neuroimaging hijinx as Earth makes 1 rotation on its journey around the Sun! https://t.co/u4pQJ4AR8p
user.name: OHBMX

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX 1/6 Our brain is designed to operate in the natural world. Recent work in fMRI of naturalistic stimuli has opened up amazing avenues of research. In this talk we look at an obvious question: do men and women process movies differently? 👦👩‍🦰🧠💻 #OHBMx

user.description:
Neuroscientist in training, Engineer
Meditator, Life long student
user.name: Vaibhav Tripathi

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX 2/6 We used the Human Connectome Project(HCP) 7T dataset with a subset of 134 subjects(67 females). Each subject underwent 4 runs of 15 minutes of the audiovisual stimulus. Each run had 3 clips either from Hollywood movies or Non-Hollywood Indie movies in English language. #OHBMx https://t.co/ppEt3Acigr

user.description:
Neuroscientist in training, Engineer
Meditator, Life long student
user.name: Vaibhav Tripathi

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX 3/6 Functional Connectivity(FC) during movie watching was computed with nodes(360 parcels or 22 sections) defined in HCP-MMP atlas. T-test calculated differences for each cell in the FC matrix. #OHBMx https://t.co/VgxBJiUWPn

user.description:
Neuroscientist in training, Engineer
Meditator, Life long student
user.name: Vaibhav Tripathi

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX 4/6 Functional connectivity was compared across the different clips for both the genders. One way ANOVA results are computed across FC of each clip individually. #OHBMx https://t.co/5yYoeYZ3xe

user.description:
Neuroscientist in training, Engineer
Meditator, Life long student
user.name: Vaibhav Tripathi

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX 5/6 Intersubject correlation(ISC) analysis was performed for the parcel averaged time-series signals. Parcels in the right frontal lateral cortex(44, AVI, 6r, IFJa, PEF, IFSp) and left inferior temporal regions(VVC, FFC) are more correlated in 👦(r=0.48) than 👩‍🦰(r=0.35). #OHBMx https://t.co/YsLXqBjqLZ

user.description:
Neuroscientist in training, Engineer
Meditator, Life long student
user.name: Vaibhav Tripathi

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX 6/6 Gender differences have been reported in anatomical, functional and connectivity. We expanded this to movie processing in the 🧠. PCC, insula, dlPFC, mid-cingulate and mPFC are regions which differ in FC/ISC correlations across genders for naturalistic movies. #OHBMx

tweets.full_text:
#OHBMx-66 ✳ #talk

Benjamin Balas @bjbalas*, A Saville

*North Dakota State University

▶ Developmental Changes in ERP responses to Natural Texture Statistics

#Developmental #sensory

user.description: OHBM EquinoX Twitter conference 20/03/2020; 24 hrs of neuroimaging hijinx as Earth makes 1 rotation on its journey around the Sun! https://t.co/u4pQJ4AR8p
user.name: OHBMX

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX 1) Natural images have lawful properties that the adult visual system is tuned to. For example, adults show increased sensitivity for patterns with amplitude spectrum fall-off coefficients close to those observed in natural scenes. #OHBMx

user.description: Vision Scientist, comics fan, retro-gamer, and dad.
user.name: Ben Balas

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX 2) Kid’s visual systems continue to develop to adult-like levels of contrast sensitivity, spatial frequency discrimination, and contour integration during middle childhood. While some  low-level mechanisms are mature early in childhood, others are not adult-like until 10. #OHBMx

user.description: Vision Scientist, comics fan, retro-gamer, and dad.
user.name: Ben Balas

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX 3) We investigated whether 5-10 y.o. kids were sensitive to deviations from natural image statistics. We examined the response of the P1 and N1 ERP components to two kinds of deviation: contrast negation and the application of texture synthesis models. #OHBMx https://t.co/yloOSKIazX

user.description: Vision Scientist, comics fan, retro-gamer, and dad.
user.name: Ben Balas

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX 4) These manipulations target different scales of natural image statistics: Contrast negation preserves global layout, while reversing local edge polarity. Texture synthesis matches statistics in small-scale neighborhoods, but disrupts larger scale visual structure. #OHBMx https://t.co/znNKmrUrzr

user.description: Vision Scientist, comics fan, retro-gamer, and dad.
user.name: Ben Balas

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX 5) At the P1 component, we found that only young children (5-7 years) were sensitive to contrast polarity (slower P1 latencies to negative-contrast images). At the N1 component, we observed main effects of synthetic appearance and contrast polarity in all age groups. #OHBMx https://t.co/CYjZZjXMGo

user.description: Vision Scientist, comics fan, retro-gamer, and dad.
user.name: Ben Balas

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX 6) Why do young children show early-stage sensitivity to contrast polarity but older Os don’t? This may reflect the end of a sort of “pre-constancy” version of natural image processing that hasn't yet developed fully invariant recognition. Or it could be something else. 😀 #OHBMx

user.description: Vision Scientist, comics fan, retro-gamer, and dad.
user.name: Ben Balas

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX Hi everyone, this is Lucina Uddin from the Brain Connectivity and Cognition Laboratory at the University of Miami (https://t.co/teN1rwxl41). I’m excited to be delivering my first Twitter Keynote for #OHBMequinox #OHBMx @OHBM! https://t.co/iiTkjEirs8

user.description: Edgy cognitive neuroscientist
user.name: Lucina Uddin

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @OHBM 2) I’d like to share with you some theoretical work with @bttyeo and @Nathan_Spreng . We've been thinking about how cognitive and network neuroscience can move towards a universal taxonomy of brain networks. Here they are during better times in Singapore (2018) #OHBMx https://t.co/j9wQdWUANE

user.description: Edgy cognitive neuroscientist
user.name: Lucina Uddin

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @OHBM @bttyeo @Nathan_Spreng 3) Why do we need this? Though the idea that the brain is composed of multiple macro-scale functional networks is ubiquitous in cognitive neuroscience, we have yet to reach consensus on terminology, making it difficult to compare findings from different research groups. #OHBMx https://t.co/SdrSyGrwoY

user.description: Edgy cognitive neuroscientist
user.name: Lucina Uddin

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @OHBM @bttyeo @Nathan_Spreng 4) What naming conventions, if universally adopted, will provide the most utility and facilitate communication amongst researchers? Let’s start with something relatively uncontroversial, like networks involved in visual or motor function. #OHBMx https://t.co/nF2TXmqpdl

user.description: Edgy cognitive neuroscientist
user.name: Lucina Uddin

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @OHBM @bttyeo @Nathan_Spreng 5) We propose that a scheme incorporating anatomical terminology should provide the foundation for a network taxonomy. Instead of naming networks after our favorite cognitive processes, we could build a taxonomy grounded in objective anatomical criteria, such as this #OHBMx. https://t.co/fCqivBWzOD

user.description: Edgy cognitive neuroscientist
user.name: Lucina Uddin

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @OHBM @bttyeo @Nathan_Spreng 6) Of course, there will be controversies. For example, we must consider whether the so-called “salience”, “cingulo-opercular”, and “ventral attention” networks constitute distinct entities, or represent versions of the same network. #OHBMx https://t.co/kt5j99bt2z

user.description: Edgy cognitive neuroscientist
user.name: Lucina Uddin

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @OHBM @bttyeo @Nathan_Spreng 7) Likewise, what about the so-called "central executive/cognitive control/multiple demand/frontoparietal network"? Are all researchers using these terms referring to the same entity? #OHBMx https://t.co/MQNrgYKhcq

user.description: Edgy cognitive neuroscientist
user.name: Lucina Uddin

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @OHBM @bttyeo @Nathan_Spreng 8) For starters, we might delineate “occipital”, “pericentral”, “dorsal frontoparietal”, “lateral frontoparietal”, “midcingulo-insular”, and “medial frontoparietal” networks. Corresponding cognitive terms are visual, somatomotor, attention, control, salience, and default. #OHBMx https://t.co/QdaVp1XYdx

user.description: Edgy cognitive neuroscientist

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @OHBM @bttyeo @Nathan_Spreng 9) Now that I’ve got everyone worked up, let’s discuss some outstanding issues. What about dynamics? Inter-individual variability? *UPenn

▶ Functional Brain Network Development During Early Childhood

#Connectivity #Developmental #Networks

user.description: OHBM EquinoX Twitter conference 20/03/2020; 24 hrs of neuroimaging hijinx as Earth makes 1 rotation on its journey around the Sun! https://t.co/u4pQJ4AR8p
user.name: OHBMX

tweets.full_text:
@OHBMequinoX @anneparkt @julia_a_leonard @DaniSBassett @allymackey Thanks for having me!

1. Kids develop rapidly early in childhood, as any parent can tell you. What changes in functional brain network architecture occur during early childhood? #OHBMx https://t.co/fOozowPi3K

user.description: Neuroscience Ph.D. candidate at UPenn | dev cog neuro | networks | environment | she/her
user.name: Ursula Tooley

tweets.full_text:
@OHBMequinoX @anneparkt @julia_a_leonard @DaniSBassett @allymackey 2. We examined the brain networks of a cross-sectional sample of 70 kids ages 4-10, controlling for motion, sex, total amount of data, and average network weight. 

Measures of network segregation are consistently positively associated with age. #OHBMx https://t.co/CsRt3hue7d

user.description: Neuroscience Ph.D. candidate at UPenn | dev cog neuro | networks | environment | she/her
user.name: Ursula Tooley

user.description: Neuroscience Ph.D. candidate at UPenn | dev cog neuro | networks | environment | she/her
user.name: Ursula Tooley

tweets.full_text:
@OHBMequinoX @anneparkt @julia_a_leonard @DaniSBassett @allymackey 4. But what *really* drives ↑ segregation is conn. between the default and attentional systems, which is strongly neg. associated with age.  

This suggests increasing separation between externally-directed attention and internally-oriented cognition as kids get older. #OHBMx https://t.co/P2SH022gFm

user.description: Neuroscience Ph.D. candidate at UPenn | dev cog neuro | networks | environment | she/her
user.name: Ursula Tooley

tweets.full_text:
@OHBMequinoX @anneparkt @julia_a_leonard @DaniSBassett @allymackey 5. Interestingly, connectivity between the visual and dorsal attention systems was *positively* associated with age.

This hints at the continued development of top-down attentional processes in early childhood. #OHBMx https://t.co/gkwUhCrHzB

user.description: Neuroscience Ph.D. candidate at UPenn | dev cog neuro | networks | environment | she/her
user.name: Ursula Tooley

tweets.full_text:
@OHBMequinoX @anneparkt @julia_a_leonard @DaniSBassett @allymackey In early childhood, kids’ brain networks are becoming increasingly refined. Future analyses will examine links to cognition, how early experience might shape these brain networks, and longitudinal changes in brain network architecture. #OHBMx 

Thanks all!

▶ EEG fingerprinting

tweets.full_text:
@OHBMequinoX 2. Most approaches need arbitrary choices: 
- frequency band definition
- selection of correlation metric for FC
- threshold to reconstruct a network
But, EEG exhibits a 1/f-like PS - an aperiodic component that may be characterized in terms of slope and offset
#OHBMx https://t.co/8cKjUD6nMQ

user.description: Assistant Professor of Computer Engineering @univca interested in M/EEG Brain Networks. Dad. RTs are (generally) bookmarks.
user.name: Matteo Fraschini

tweets.full_text:
@OHBMequinoX 3. Despite the interest in this approach, it has not been investigated yet how it depicts individual variability in EEG. Here, we quantified the aperiodic component of PS (spectral slope and the offset) and used these features to identify subjects in a large EEG dataset
#OHBMx https://t.co/GjT2Z5cQYX

user.description: Assistant Professor of Computer Engineering @univca interested in M/EEG Brain Networks. Dad. RTs are (generally) bookmarks.
user.name: Matteo Fraschini

tweets.full_text:
@OHBMequinoX 4. Here we:
- applied ADJUST to reduce the effects of artifacts
- segmented (1m) RS EEGs into 5 non-overlapping epochs
- extracted aperiodic component features (FOOOF toolbox)
- extracted periodic component features (the relative power of theta, alpha, beta, and gamma)
#OHBMx

#OHBMx-71 ✳ #talk

John Samuelsson @JohnSamuelsson1*, P Sundaram, S Khan @dr_sheraz, M Sereno, M Hämäläinen @mshamalai

*Massachusetts Institute of Technology

▶ Detectability of Cerebellar Activity with MEG and EEG

#Tools #Cerebellum

user.description: OHBM EquinoX Twitter conference 20/03/2020; 24 hrs of neuroimaging hijinx as Earth makes 1 rotation on its journey around the Sun! https://t.co/u4pQJ4AR8p
user.name: OHBMX

tweets.full_text:
@OHBMequinoX @dr_sheraz @mshamalai (1) The cerebellum contains more than 70 % of all neurons in the brain and has been implicated in diseases such as schizophrenia and PD. 

The cerebellum has, however, remained largely overlooked and its electrophysiology remains poorly characterized in health and disease. #OHBMx

@OHBMequinoX @dr_sheraz @mshamalai (2) Here we investigated if MEG or EEG could be used to detect cerebellar activity by performing simulations using a high-resolution tessellation of the cerebellar cortex constructed from repetitive 9.4 T structural MRI of an ex vivo cerebellum (image). #OHBMx https://t.co/4THFEcUDS5

@OHBMequinoX @dr_sheraz @mshamalai (3) Using the detailed cerebellar model, we could see that the cerebellar signals from single dipoles were on average about 30 % weaker than the cortical signals, and cancellation was 20-50 % worse due to the tightly folded cerebellar cortex (image). #OHBMx https://t.co/bQJZq5xND5

@OHBMequinoX @dr_sheraz @mshamalai (4) Combined, these two effects make the net cerebellar signals on average 30 - 60 % weaker than the cortical signals. 

But the variation in these results are quite large as a function of position, so we made M/EEG sensitivity maps of the cerebellum (image). #OHBMx https://t.co/6g4SAEuNyd

@OHBMequinoX @dr_sheraz @mshamalai (5)We see that MEG and EEG have complementary sensitivity distributions; EEG is sensitive to activity in the anterior lobe and MEG to activity in the posterior lobe. 

Both are optimally sensitive to activity in crus I/lobule VI which activate during working memory tasks. #OHBMx https://t.co/AuXd9nV47y

@OHBMequinoX @dr_sheraz @mshamalai (6) To conclude, our simulations suggested that the average cerebellar signal in MEG and EEG is only 30–60 % weaker than the cortical signal and that MEG and EEG have highly complementary sensitivity distributions. 
Check out the full article here
https://t.co/22TXRjtywU 
#OHBMx

#OHBMx-75 ✳ #talk

Davide Valeriani @DavideValeriani*

*Harvard Medical School

▶ Merging humans and machines with collaborative brain-computer interfaces

#Decision

user.description: OHBM EquinoX Twitter conference 20/03/2020; 24 hrs of neuroimaging hijinx as Earth makes 1 rotation on its journey around the Sun! https://t.co/u4pQJ4AR8p
user.name: OHBMX

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX 1) Recognizing a person in a crowded environment is challenging for both humans and machines. How can we use neurotechnologies and machine learning to make better decisions? Well, we can make cyborgs! 🤖 #OHBMx https://t.co/YR9KoKdH8B

user.description: Decision making + neuroimaging + machine learning + BCI. Research fellow at Harvard @SimonyanLab. Maintainer of @matplotlib's blog, @harvardmpa board.
user.name: Davide Valeriani, PhD

tweets.full_text:
@OHBMequinoX 2) We showed 10 human participants pictures of crowded environments for 300 ms and asked them to decide whether a target person was present (try it!). 
The same task was also performed by a pre-trained residual neural network (ResNet, code: https://t.co/pXKvSxfSJJ). 👩👨🖥️#OHBMx https://t.co/kCE2AhB1Mq

user.description: Decision making + neuroimaging + machine learning + BCI. Research fellow at Harvard @SimonyanLab. Maintainer of @matplotlib's blog, @harvardmpa board.
user.name: Davide Valeriani, PhD

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX 3) Collaborative brain-computer interfaces (#BCI) decoded the human decision confidence (probability of correct decision) from #EEG activity using logistic regression. The ResNet confidence was estimated as difference between target and current face encodings. #OHBMx 🧠 https://t.co/Auvk2Sgvkr

user.description: Decision making + neuroimaging + machine learning + BCI. Research fellow at Harvard @SimonyanLab. Maintainer of @matplotlib's blog, @harvardmpa board.
user.name: Davide Valeriani, PhD

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX 4) Since confidence correlates with correctness, we used it to weigh individual decisions and obtain group decisions in different types of simulated groups, with or without the BCI and the ResNet. Performance were assessed using cross-validation. #OHBMx 👨‍👩‍👧‍👧 https://t.co/Yt5kdWLznF

user.description: Decision making + neuroimaging + machine learning + BCI. Research fellow at Harvard @SimonyanLab. Maintainer of @matplotlib's blog, @harvardmpa board.
user.name: Davide Valeriani, PhD

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX 5) Combining human decisions, BCIs, and ResNet (orange line) yielded significantly more accurate decisions (up to 35%) than equally-sized human groups. Also, the average group of 5+ BCI-assisted humans and the ResNet was more accurate than the ResNet alone. #OHBMx 📈 https://t.co/HCfDqEpyNy

user.description: Decision making + neuroimaging + machine learning + BCI. Research fellow at Harvard @SimonyanLab. Maintainer of @matplotlib's blog, @harvardmpa board.
user.name: Davide Valeriani, PhD

tweets.full_text:
@OHBMequinoX 6) To sum up: machines should work with us, rather than replacing us, if we want to make the best decisions! More details on https://t.co/ORzZshMLAv.
Thanks to @profrpoli for advising, @Ele_Adami for the artwork, and you all for reading! #OHBMx 🙇‍♂️ https://t.co/J4tNRjkXp5

@OHBMequinoX @AustinLuor @aahanabajra 1
Motion in fMRI hurts our stats. Including 6 canonical motion parameters as covariates (still common) is probably not optimal.

In resting state, “scrubbing” has worked well. Maybe this is also true for task fMRI? We investigated.

#OHBMx https://t.co/MD5e9nnPsr

▶ Applications of Informational Connectivity

user.name: OHBMX

tweets.full_text:
@OHBMequinoX 1. MVPA can detect information in distributed patterns of fMRI activity. Functional connectivity measures shared fluctuations over time. Informational connectivity (IC) combines these (https://t.co/V9ZSx3yRU8). IC has now been applied to various Qs. Let's look at some!
#OHBMx https://t.co/JP3MQFfiPp

user.description: Assistant Prof of Psychology @ U. of Pittsburgh. Cognitive neuroscience, memory, learning, perception, fMRI pattern analysis. Born in 🇯🇪, Live in 🇺🇸. He/him
user.name: Marc Coutanche

tweets.full_text:
@OHBMequinoX 2. @Derek_J_Huffman & Stark examined categorical representations in MTL cortex (https://t.co/h3gBSGdX9N). IC between PHC & RSC/PCC was significant for faces vs scenes, not faces vs objects - suggesting stimulus-dependent modulation of their common pattern discriminability
#OHBMx https://t.co/iv1nSzVMxN

user.description: Assistant Prof of Psychology @ U. of Pittsburgh. Cognitive neuroscience, memory, learning, perception, fMRI pattern analysis. Born in 🇯🇪, Live in 🇺🇸. He/him
user.name: Marc Coutanche

tweets.full_text:
@OHBMequinoX @Derek_J_Huffman 3. @mariam_s_aly & Turk-Browne asked how attention promotes episodic encoding (https://t.co/P1bYwW6BTA). IC (for attentional state) between CA2/CA3/DG & RSC was greater for later remembered trials - perhaps showing how visuospatial info is transformed to LT memory
#OHBMx https://t.co/SReadO2gZT

user.description: Assistant Prof of Psychology @ U. of Pittsburgh. Cognitive neuroscience, memory, learning, perception, fMRI pattern analysis. Born in 🇯🇪, Live in 🇺🇸. He/him
user.name: Marc Coutanche

tweets.full_text:
@OHBMequinoX @Derek_J_Huffman @mariam_s_aly 4. @raphael_koster et al asked how hippocampus supports both episodic encoding & integration across experiences (https://t.co/B9eLFjO0Te). Laminar & direct MTL links had stronger IC than did indirect. Laminar connections may reflect direct flow of info between EC layers
#OHBMx https://t.co/6TTiPXO2tL

user.description: Assistant Prof of Psychology @ U. of Pittsburgh. Cognitive neuroscience, memory, learning, perception, fMRI pattern analysis. Born in 🇯🇪, Live in 🇺🇸. He/him
user.name: Marc Coutanche

tweets.full_text:
@OHBMequinoX @Derek_J_Huffman @mariam_s_aly @raphael_koster 5. Finally, with Thompson-Schill, I investigated how learning real-world size of concepts changes early visual patterns (https://t.co/V9ZSx3yRU8). IC between EVC & angular gyrus for similarly-sized animals increased after learning, perhaps from new top-down info
#OHBMx https://t.co/CltRBNr7zT

user.description: Assistant Prof of Psychology @ U. of Pittsburgh. Cognitive neuroscience, memory, learning, perception, fMRI pattern analysis. Born in 🇯🇪, Live in 🇺🇸. He/him
user.name: Marc Coutanche

@OHBMequinoX @Derek_J_Huffman @mariam_s_aly @raphael_koster 6. To summarize, IC can tell us a lot about how regions work together, particularly in exchanging fine-grained (MVP) information. I’m looking forward to future examples! (If you prefer a video overview of method: https://t.co/zfc9QYauK9). Questions always welcome!

Ceren Tozlu @crntozlu*, K Jamison, S Gauthier, A Kuceyeski @AmyKuceyeski

*Department of Radiology-Weill Cornell Medicine

▶ Brain connectivity predicts MS patients’ impairment level

#Connectivity #Dynamics #Modeling #Networks

user.description: OHBM EquinoX Twitter conference 20/03/2020; 24 hrs of neuroimaging hijinx as Earth makes 1 rotation on its journey around the Sun! https://t.co/u4pQJ4AR8p
user.name: OHBMX

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @AmyKuceyeski 1/ In Multiple Sclerosis (MS), the correlation between the impairment and disease burden measured with conventional MRI is poor. Therefore, structural and static/dynamic functional connectivity (SC,sFC,&dFC) may be used to better understand variability of impairment in MS. #OHBMx https://t.co/wegHAgtGOz

user.description: Postdoc in the Department of Radiology at Weill Cornell Medicine -  CoCo Lab
user.name: Ceren Tozlu

user.description: Postdoc in the Department of Radiology at Weill Cornell Medicine -  CoCo Lab
user.name: Ceren Tozlu

tweets.full_text:
@OHBMequinoX @AmyKuceyeski 3/ Age and gender matched 76 MS patients (23 CSI and 53 CNSI) and 15 HC were included. 
Hard-clustering and fuzzy meta-state analyses were used for dFC approach. 
An ensemble model with Random Forest was used to classify 
-HC vs MS 
-MS patients with CSI vs CNSI. #OHBMx

user.description: Postdoc in the Department of Radiology at Weill Cornell Medicine -  CoCo Lab
user.name: Ceren Tozlu

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @AmyKuceyeski 4/ The ensemble model that averaged the predictions from SC and sFC better distinguished MS vs HC (AUC=0.78). For the classification of CSI vs CNSI, the SC and dFC combination performed better (AUC=0.65) compared to the combination of SC and sFC (AUC=0.60). #OHBMx https://t.co/JOtEDA3JgN

user.description: Postdoc in the Department of Radiology at Weill Cornell Medicine -  CoCo Lab
user.name: Ceren Tozlu

user.description: Postdoc in the Department of Radiology at Weill Cornell Medicine -  CoCo Lab
user.name: Ceren Tozlu

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @AmyKuceyeski 6/ dFC better classified MS with CSIvsCNSI compared to sFC. Ensemble model has potential to help clinicians accurately predict impairment in MS and identify important SC&FC underlying these impairments, thus enabling personalized prognostics and therapeutic interventions. #OHBMx

#OHBMx-79 ✳ #talk

Maggie Mae Mell @MaggieMaeWokeUp*, G St-Yves, T Naselaris

*Medical University of SC

▶ Investigating unexplained variance with voxel-to-voxel models

#Connectivity #Modeling #Sensory

user.description: OHBM EquinoX Twitter conference 20/03/2020; 24 hrs of neuroimaging hijinx as Earth makes 1 rotation on its journey around the Sun! https://t.co/u4pQJ4AR8p
user.name: OHBMX

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX 1 Best encoding models for predicting fMRI responses in visual areas are based on Deep Neural Nets. But even DNN-based models fail to accurately predict activity to natural scenes in most voxels. Is the source of missing variance just noise or are models missing something? #OHBMx https://t.co/fHKdHkkL2M

user.description: PhD Candidate in visual computational neuroscience. She/Her 👁🧠👩🏻‍🔬👩🏼‍🎤  Opinions my own and do not represent any org I am affiliated with.
user.name: Maggie Mae Mell

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX 2 Hypothesis: A portion of missing variance is due to endogenous processes. Feedback from areas higher in or outside of visual hierarchy are not accounted for in DNN stimulus-to-voxel models. We use voxel-to-voxel models (e.g. activity in V1 predicts V2) to investigate. #OHBMx https://t.co/godPOPgzgE

user.description: PhD Candidate in visual computational neuroscience. She/Her 👁🧠👩🏻‍🔬👩🏼‍🎤  Opinions my own and do not represent any org I am affiliated with.
user.name: Maggie Mae Mell

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX 3 Vox2vox > stim2vox prediction accuracy in nearly all source/target pairs. So activity in V4, while cortically ‘distant’, can more accurately predict V1 activity than stimulus features can. We infer source of unexplained variance is shared within & between visual areas. #OHBMx https://t.co/U8g7jiyTB7

user.description: PhD Candidate in visual computational neuroscience. She/Her 👁🧠👩🏻‍🔬👩🏼‍🎤  Opinions my own and do not represent any org I am affiliated with.
user.name: Maggie Mae Mell

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX 4 Vox2vox <= stim2vox prediction accuracy when source areas in one sub’s brain predict target voxel activity in a different subject. Indicates cross-subject vox2vox models are, like stim2vox models, blind to a source of variance that is common to voxels in the same brain. #OHBMx https://t.co/ljJ7AKLCdN

user.description: PhD Candidate in visual computational neuroscience. She/Her 👁🧠👩🏻‍🔬👩🏼‍🎤  Opinions my own and do not represent any org I am affiliated with.
user.name: Maggie Mae Mell

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX 5 Source voxels w/large positive vox2vox model weights had receptive field (rf) locations that cluster near target voxels’ rf loc. Can use weights to accurately estimate “ground truth” rf loc of target voxels, including ones stim2vox fails on. Missing variance != all noise #OHBMx https://t.co/CnMy1tlUqt

user.description: PhD Candidate in visual computational neuroscience. She/Her 👁🧠👩🏻‍🔬👩🏼‍🎤  Opinions my own and do not represent any org I am affiliated with.
user.name: Maggie Mae Mell

tweets.full_text:
@OHBMequinoX 6 Conclusion: Best models don't explain a lot of variance. Do we see evidence this variance is endogenous & not noise?
Variance shared across voxels.✅
But NOT shared across subs.✅
Retinotopically mapped across long cortical distances.✅
Preprint: https://t.co/pk2zcbFUIK
#OHBMx https://t.co/fTxDNJyPvK

#OHBMx-80 ✳ #talk

Idan Blank @IdanAsherBlank*, E Fedorenko @ev_fedorenko

*UCLA

▶ An alternative to “random effects” with higher validity, reliability, and power

#Language #Memory #Methods

user.description: OHBM EquinoX Twitter conference 20/03/2020; 24 hrs of neuroimaging hijinx as Earth makes 1 rotation on its journey around the Sun! https://t.co/u4pQJ4AR8p
user.name: OHBMX

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @ev_fedorenko 1️⃣How do u pool fMRI data across ppl? Most still use voxelwise pooling in common space: group-based, random-effects (RFX) analysis. But it works only if same voxel = same function across ppl, which does not hold! (https://t.co/6bvFtdeZBZ) Fig: why RFX is really bad for you #OHBMx https://t.co/I1gnVv0Btk

user.description: Cognitive (neuro)scientist studying language at UCLA Psych (BlankLangLab). Views are my own. He/Him. RT ≠ endorsement. 🏳️‍🌈
user.name: Idan Blank

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @ev_fedorenko 2️⃣U can use a task to find FUNCTIONAL regions in each individual brain. But to eyeball maps (“blob A in brain X ~ blob B in brain Y”) is unprincipled, & hard if activity is a swath (not blobs). So @ev_fedorenko devised group-constrained, subject-specific localization (GSS) #OHBMx https://t.co/E9ji7Utv74

user.description: Cognitive (neuro)scientist studying language at UCLA Psych (BlankLangLab). Views are my own. He/Him. RT ≠ endorsement. 🏳️‍🌈
user.name: Idan Blank

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @ev_fedorenko 3️⃣GSS should be better (https://t.co/jL7IKncg4B). So we pitted it against RFX! Tested 5 networks differing in laterality, domain- & modality-specificity/generality: language (n=510 ppl), Multiple Demand (392), Default Mode (386), Theory of Mind (132), face processing (102) #OHBMx https://t.co/JKCIXRdy6a

user.description: Cognitive (neuro)scientist studying language at UCLA Psych (BlankLangLab). Views are my own. He/Him. RT ≠ endorsement. 🏳️‍🌈
user.name: Idan Blank

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @ev_fedorenko 4️⃣First we generated broad masks to constrain fROI location (top Fig). GSS = fROIs may slightly vary in location across ppl as long as within same mask. RFX = group-based fROIs (traditional). For both, effect sizes extracted w/ across run cross validation (CV; bottom Fig.) #OHBMx https://t.co/QdUqK6jVt4

user.description: Cognitive (neuro)scientist studying language at UCLA Psych (BlankLangLab). Views are my own. He/Him. RT ≠ endorsement. 🏳️‍🌈
user.name: Idan Blank

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @ev_fedorenko 5️⃣GSS ALWAYS outperformed RFX, & by a huge margin! Note: even w/ n>100, RFX totally misses some regions (0 activations, see arrows) but GSS finds robust effects; in MD, classic response is "hard>easy", but GSS-easy > RFX-hard. So RFX massively underestimates effects #OHBMx https://t.co/fjqemSGRiK

user.description: Cognitive (neuro)scientist studying language at UCLA Psych (BlankLangLab). Views are my own. He/Him. RT ≠ endorsement. 🏳️‍🌈
user.name: Idan Blank

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @ev_fedorenko 6️⃣GSS is principled, easy (toolbox: https://t.co/4akyI1ncUa) & CHEAP (for our tasks, >80% power w/ n=10). Results are valid (recall Fig1) & reliable (CV built-in). Even if you designed your expt w/o thinking GSS, you can apply it post-hoc! Cool, huh? Please stop using RFX. #OHBMx https://t.co/nBn0wWKFjU

@OHBMequinoX @BrainHacktivist 4. Evidence for double-dissociation in brain-behavior relationships: 

Increased connectivity of dlPFC (DES) was associated with higher emotion regulation (ERQ), while increased anti-correlation of dlPFC was associated with lower emotion contagion (ECS; attached figures) https://t.co/FlT29lo397

user.description: @NSERC_CRSNG Neuroscience PhD student at @UAlberta_FoMD, Interested in functional brain connectivity, #scicomm #neuroimaging

tweets.full_text: @OHBMequinoX @dimitrpantazis 1/6 A potential biomarker for Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the disruption of functional brain networks measured by MEG. Here we developed a multiple graph Gaussian embedding method with uncertainty quantification for predicting AD progression using MEG data.  #OHBMx https://t.co/mViSWcuVHV

@OHBMequinoX @dimitrpantazis 2/6 We investigate if subtle alterations in MEG brain networks can predict AD progression. Measurements is from Madrid cohort database with stable/progressive MCI and control subjects. 5 mins eye-closed resting state MEG data was collected using a 306-channel MEG system. #OHBMx https://t.co/jIv56QNJvh

@OHBMequinoX @dimitrpantazis 3/6 We computed source-level MEG brain networks using DKT atlas, and built a stochastic embedding method to learn informative embeddings with uncertainty quantification. We applied the latent embeddings to predict AD progression and quantify group-wise changes. #OHBMx https://t.co/iRCh2AJzQj

@OHBMequinoX @dimitrpantazis 4/6 With 3D stochastic encoder architecture, we transform high-dimensional MEG brain networks into a latent node-wise stochastic embedding space (i.e., multivariate normal distributions). The optimal embedding dimension obtained by performing link prediction experiments. #OHBMx https://t.co/QhwMZVa5wl

@OHBMequinoX @dimitrpantazis 5/6 The transformed MEG brain network Gaussian embedding signature is employed for subsequent important tasks of AD progression, and for effective discrimination of stable and progressive MCI. This can provide potential insights into AD phenotyping. #OHBMx https://t.co/Gvq4YS2PWF

@OHBMequinoX @dimitrpantazis 6/6 “group-wise” changing regions in preclinical stages of AD are detected using a statistic permutation approach and FDR correction with the probabilistic embeddings. Visualization results indicated that most significant regions fall into the temporal and frontal lobes. #OHBMx https://t.co/droanjWupx

quoted_status.full_text: Brain folds develop together with cytoarchitectonic regions and corticocortical connections. That folding results from a mechanical instability is now relatively well accepted. However, the pattern of these folds is still thought to reflect patterned gene expression #ohbmx https://t.co/LxmbfKLRX5
